question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
The child was / gazing longingly / at the toy.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 1 Dec Shift-3)
solution:
Correct Answer:No error

Explanation:
Let‚Äôs analyse each part of the sentence:

  • "The child was" ‚Äì correct subject and auxiliary verb for past continuous tense. ‚úÖ

  • "gazing longingly" ‚Äì grammatically correct; "gazing" (looking steadily) + "longingly" (with desire) is a valid verb-adverb combination. ‚úÖ

  • "at the toy" ‚Äì correct prepositional phrase indicating the object of gaze. ‚úÖ

The sentence is grammatically correct in structure, tense, and word usage.

‚úÖ Therefore, the correct answer is: No error.

question:

question:

question:
The given sentence contains an error. Select the option that correctly rectifies the error.
He is the better-looking hero in the entire film industry.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 13_Sept_Shift-3)
option_1: He is the good-looking hero than the entire film industry.
option_2: He is the best-looking hero in the entire film industry.
option_3: He is the best-looking hero more than the entire film industry.
option_4: He is the good-looking hero in the entire film industry.
solution:
The option that correctly rectifies the error is: "He is the best-looking hero in the entire film industry."

The corrected sentence maintains the proper comparative form by using "best-looking" to compare the hero's appearance within the film industry.

question:
The sentence below has been divided into three parts. Select the part of the sentence that has an error. If the sentence has no error, select the option 'No Error'.
Chasing the white stag through the/ forests, never catching it, of/ course, for it is a creature of legend.

(IB ACIO 2023 T-1 : 17 Jan S2)
option_2: course, for it is a creature of legend.
option_3: Chasing the white stag through the
option_4: forests, never catching it, of
solution:
Explanation:

Let's break it down part by part:

üü© Part 1: "Chasing the white stag through the"

‚úÖ Grammatically correct.
"Chasing" is a present participle (verb-ing) used to describe an ongoing or habitual action.

üü© Part 2: "forests, never catching it, of"

‚úÖ Correct.
"never catching it" is the continuation of the participial phrase.
"of" is part of the idiomatic expression "of course", so it must be followed by "course" in the next part.

üü© Part 3: "course, for it is a creature of legend."

‚úÖ Correct.

  • "of course" is used parenthetically (within commas), meaning ‚Äúobviously.‚Äù

  • "for" means "because" (‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ø), and the clause "it is a creature of legend" justifies why it‚Äôs never caught.

üß† Explanation:

This sentence is a grammatically valid complex sentence made up of participial and independent clauses. It uses correct punctuation and idiomatic expressions.

‚úÖ Final Answer: No error

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
Aarav‚Äôs mother / speaks four languages / fluently.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 18 Apr S3 (4 to 5 PM))
solution:
Explanation:

Step-by-step Analysis:

  • Part A: ‚ÄúAarav‚Äôs mother‚Äù

  • This is a possessive noun phrase and acts as the subject of the sentence.

  • Grammatically correct.

  • ‚úÖ No error here.

  • Part B: ‚Äúspeaks four languages‚Äù

  • Verb Phrase ‚Äì "speaks" is the correct third person singular form of "speak" to match the subject "mother".

  • "four languages" is a grammatically and semantically valid object.

  • ‚úÖ No error here either.

  • Part C: ‚Äúfluently‚Äù

  • Adverb modifying the verb "speaks".

  • "Fluently" is in the right place (after the object). In English, adverbs of manner can appear at the end of the sentence, before the verb, or after the verb + object, all of which are correct.

  • ‚úÖ No error here.

  • Option D: ‚ÄúNo error‚Äù

  • Since all parts are grammatically and semantically correct, this is the right answer.

‚úÖ Correct Answer: No error

question:
Parts of the given sentence have been given as options. One of them may contain a grammatical error. Select the option that has the error. If there is no error, select ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô.
The food was not as delicious as we had expected.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-2)
solution:
Solution:
The sentence "The food was not as delicious as we had expected." is grammatically correct. It uses the structure "not as...as" properly to compare the actual quality of the food with the expectation.
"The food was not" is the correct beginning for a negative statement.
"as delicious as" is the correct comparative structure used for equal comparison.
"we had expected" is correctly in the past perfect tense, suitable when comparing a past expectation with a past event.
Since all segments are correct, there is no grammatical error in the sentence.

question:
Parts of the given sentence have been given as options. One of them may contain a grammatical error. Select the option that has the error. If there is no error, select ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô.
Specialists say that this method speeds up language learning tremendously.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-2)
solution:
Solution:
The sentence "Specialists say that this method speeds up language learning tremendously." is grammatically correct.

  • "Specialists say that" is a valid reporting structure.

  • "this method speeds up" is a correct present tense verb phrase.

  • "language learning tremendously" correctly uses the adverb "tremendously" to modify the verb phrase.

There is no grammatical error in any part of the sentence.

Answer: Option B (No error).

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
Even though I had been boxing for three years, I had no idea that I can beat somebody in the ring.

(SSC CPO 2022 T-2)
option_2: Even though I had been boxing for three years
option_3: I can beat somebody in the ring
option_4: I had no idea that
solution:
Solution:

  • The sentence mixes past perfect ("had been boxing") with present tense ("can beat").

  • The phrase "I can beat somebody in the ring" should be in past tense to match the rest of the sentence.

  • Correct form: "I could beat somebody in the ring."

  • Therefore, the error is in the segment: "I can beat somebody in the ring."

Answer: (c) I can beat somebody in the ring

question:

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don't find any error, mark 'No error' as your answer.
The project was completed / more quicker / than expected.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (01-July Shift 3))
solution:
The part that contains the error is:

more quicker.

Explanation:

  • The correct comparison should be "quicker" rather than "more quicker". When forming the comparative of adjectives that already end in -er, such as "quick", we do not use "more". The correct phrase is simply "quicker".

So, the corrected sentence would be:
"The project was completed quicker than expected."

Thus, the error is in the phrase "more quicker."

question:

solution:

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Urgent activities are those things / that you must do immediately, / as they require quick action / and cannot be put on.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (03-July Shift 2))

option_2: that you must do immediately
option_3: as they require quick action

The segment that contains a grammatical error is "and cannot be put on."

Final Answer: and cannot be put on

question:
Identify the error in the following sentence and select the option with the correct use of the phrasal verb.
The police inspector was trying to give out the contradicting stories in the scene of the accident.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (04-July Shift 4))
option_1: The police inspector was trying to lighten up the contradicting stories in the scene of the accident.
option_2: The police inspector was trying to rush out the contradicting stories in the scene of the accident.
option_3: The police inspector was trying to sign up the contradicting stories in the scene of the accident.
option_4: The police inspector was trying to sort out the contradicting stories in the scene of the accident.
solution:
Answer: The police inspector was trying to sort out the contradicting stories in the scene of the accident.

Solution:

  • Error: The phrase "give out the contradicting stories" is incorrect here.

  • Correction: The correct phrasal verb is "sort out," which means to resolve or clarify conflicting information.

  • Part of speech corrected: Verb phrase (phrasal verb usage).

question:
The following sentence has been divided into four segments. Identify the segment that contains an error.
How long are you working / for your current employer / and why don‚Äôt you / look for better opportunities?

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (08-July Shift 4))
option_4: How long are you working
solution:
Correct Answer: How long are you working

Explanation:
The error lies in the use of the present continuous tense ("are you working") for a situation that refers to past duration up to the present.

  • The correct tense should be present perfect continuous to express an action that started in the past and continues into the present.

  • So, it should be: "How long have you been working".

Correct sentence:
"How long have you been working for your current employer, and why don‚Äôt you look for better opportunities?"

question:

solution:

Therefore, the grammatical error is in the segment "Everyone have".

question:

question:

question:
Select the sentence that has a grammatical error.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.40_28-Oct_Shift-2)

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.

solution:

Explanation:
The phrasal verb "thrown up" is incorrect in this context.

  • The correct phrasal verb should be "thrown out", meaning to forcefully remove someone (‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§®‡§æ).

Correct sentence: "The manager had thrown out the drunk people sitting inside his office premises."

question:

A good lawyer / always looks in the / case before he / attends court.

solution:
Answer: a) always looks in the

The error lies in the phrase "looks in the".

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
He cheated in the [A] / examination, making his [B] / already-falling academic [C] / credentials worst. [D]

(SSC MTS 2024 S.6_07-Oct_Shift-1)
solution:
Correct answer:D

Explanation:

The phrase "credentials worst" is grammatically incorrect. The correct comparative/superlative form in this context should be "worse," not "worst."

Let‚Äôs break it down:

  • "Worst" is the superlative form, used when comparing three or more things.

  • "Worse" is the comparative form, used when comparing two things or when something is getting more bad than before.

Here, the sentence implies that his academic credentials, which were already falling, became even more bad‚Äîso we use "worse."

Correct sentence:
"He cheated in the examination, making his already-falling academic credentials worse."

Therefore, the error is in segment D.

question:
Select the grammatically correct statement from among the given options.
A. The Taj Mahal is an iconic building. Visiting it is an experience worth remembering forever.
B.Taj Mahal is a iconic building. Visiting it is an experience worth remembering forever.
C.The Taj Mahal is an iconic building. Visiting it is a experience worth remembering forever.
D.A Taj Mahal is a iconic building. Visiting it is an experience worth remembering forever.

(SSC CPO 2022 T-2)
solution:
Solution:

  • Option (A) is correct because:

  • It uses the definite article "The" correctly before "Taj Mahal."

  • It correctly uses "an iconic building" (using "an" before a vowel sound).

  • It uses "an experience" (correct article before a vowel sound).

  • Other options have errors in articles ("a" instead of "an," missing "The," or incorrect article usage).

Answer: (a) A

question:
In the following sentence the underlined part contains as error. Alternatives to the underlined part are given as options. Select the correct alternative.
The water near the coast was sÃ≤hÃ≤aÃ≤lÃ≤lÃ≤oÃ≤wÃ≤eÃ≤rÃ≤ and clean.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.61_13-Nov_Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: shallow

Explanation:
In the sentence, the word "shallow" is used correctly in its base form to describe the water near the coast.
Since "and clean" follows it, both adjectives describe the water equally without comparison, so the simple form "shallow" is appropriate.
Comparative forms like "more shallow" or "shallower" would be used only when directly comparing two things.
Superlative forms like "shallowest" or "the shallowest" are used when indicating the extreme degree among three or more.

Here, no comparison is made, so "shallow" is correct.

question:

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Give me / a book / that is / on the table.

(SSC Steno 2022 : 18 Nov S-1)
solution:
Answer: (d) a book

Explanation:
The phrase "Give me a book that is on the table." is grammatically correct and natural. Here:

  • "a book" refers to any one book among possibly many on the table.

  • The clause "that is on the table" specifies which book is being asked for.

Using "the book" instead of "a book" would suggest a specific, known book, possibly only one on the table. Since the sentence aims to request any one suitable book, "a book" is appropriate here.

All segments in the sentence are grammatically correct, so there is no error in the given sentence.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
The world will/ not stop for you, / it will keep on going.

solution:
Answer: (d) No error
Explanation: The sentence ‚ÄúThe world will not stop for you, it will keep on going.‚Äù is grammatically correct.
 The future tense is used correctly: ‚Äúwill not stop‚Äù and ‚Äúwill keep on going.‚Äù
 The subject‚Äìverb agreement is also correct.
 The comma joining the two independent clauses is acceptable, especially in informal writing.
 ‚úÖ Hence, the correct answer is: (d) No error.

solution:

‚ùå Why Other Options Are Not Errors:
